Test Assertion Macros



#define TDOG_ASSERT(a)
 Asserts that the test condition "a" is true (the test fails if it is not).
#define TDOG_ASSERT_MSG(a, msg)
 Asserts that "a" is true (the test fails if it is not) and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(a, b)
 Asserts that "a" equals "b" (the test fails if they are not).
#define TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, msg)
 Asserts that "a" equals "b" (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL(a, b)
 Asserts that strings "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not).
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, msg)
 Asserts that strings "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL(a, b)
 Compares strings "a" and "b" case insensitively and asserts that they are equal (the test fails if they are not).
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, msg)
 Compares strings "a" and "b" case insensitively and asserts that they are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_INT_EQUAL(a, b)
 Asserts that integer values "a" and "b" are equal.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_INT_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, msg)
 Asserts that integer values "a" and "b" are equal and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL(a, b, delta)
 Asserts that floating point (double) values "a" and "b" are equal to within the range +/- delta.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, delta, msg)
 Asserts that floating point (double) values "a" and "b" are equal to within the range +/- delta and records the custom message in the test report.
#define TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL(a, b, cnt)
 Asserts that the content of arrays "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not).
#define TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL_MSG(a, b, cnt, msg)
 Asserts that the content of arrays "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.

 Asserts that the expression throws an exception of the specified type.

 Asserts that the expression does not throw an exception.

Other Message and States Macros



#define TDOG_TEST_MSG(msg)
 Writes a information message string to the test report.
#define TDOG_TEST_VAL(msg, val)
 Writes a formatted value information string to the test report.
#define TDOG_TEST_FAIL(msg)
 Increments the test case's failure condition count, thus ensuring that the test fails, and writes the supplied message to the test report.
#define TDOG_TEST_PASS(msg)
 Writes a "pass condition" informational message to the test report.
#define TDOG_TEST_ERROR(msg)
 Puts the test case into an error state and writes the supplied message to the test report.
#define TDOG_HAS_TEST_FAILED()
 Provides indication that the test has failed (or raised a test error).

Detailed Description

TEST-DOG test macros.

Define Documentation

#define TDOG_TEST_CASE ( test_name   ) 

Creates a test case and registers it with a global instance of of the TEST-DOG test runner class.

A test can be created as follows:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(number_test)
 {
   int num_beast = 665;
   TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(666, ++num_beast); // Passes
 }

The test code should not return any result.

The test name should not contain spaces, as it will be used internally to form the basis of a C++ data type.

The test case will automatically be register* with the global testdog::runner class, and the test can then be executed by calling the runner::run() method.

Tests are normally executed in the runner in the order that they are declared. However, tests can also be executed individually, as follows:

 testdog::runner::global().run(RUN_TEST, "number_test");

Additionally, tests can be grouped together within "test suites" as follows:

 TDOG_TEST_SUITE(beast_suite)
 {
   TDOG_TEST_CASE(number_test)
   {
     int num_beast = 665;
     TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(666, ++num_beast); // Passes
   }
 }

Test suites allow test cases to be run or disabled as a group.

It is also possible to disable the automatic registration of test cases. See the runner::register_test() method for further information.

Parameters:
[in] test_name The test name
See also:
TDOG_TEST_SUITE(), TDOG_TEST_FIXTURE()
#define TDOG_TEST_FIXTURE ( test_name,
fixture_type   ) 

Creates a test with custom data and setup/teardown functionality.

This macro is similar to TDOG_TEST_CASE(), except that it that it requires a data type which it will instantiate when the test is executed. Test setup and teardown code can, therefore, be implemented in the data type's constructor and destructor.

For example:

 // Declare fixture type
 struct person_t
 {
   std::string name;
   int age;
   person_t() : name("unknown"), age(25) {} // setup
   ~person_t() {} // teardown
 };

 // Create test fixture
 TDOG_TEST_FIXTURE(test_person, person_t)
 {
   TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL_MSG("unknown", name, "Person name test");
   TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG(25, age, "Default age");
 }

Note, in the example, how the fixture's data members are accessible in the test implementation. Also note that the fixture's constructor will be called when the test starts, and it's destructor called when the test ends.

In the event that either the constructor or destructor throw an exception, an error condition will be recorded and the test case will be deemed to have failed.

Parameters:
[in] test_name The test name
[in] fixture_type The fixture type
See also:
TDOG_TEST_CASE(), TDOG_TEST_SUITE()
#define TDOG_TEST_SUITE ( suite_name   ) 

Allows test cases to be grouped into "suites".

A test suite allows test cases to be run or disabled in groups. The suite name will be used directly as a C++ namespace around test cases, so it should not contain spaces or conflict with existing namespaces. Declaring tests within namespaced suites also allows the same test name can be used in multiple contexts.

In the following example, two test cases are defined inside a test suite:

 TDOG_TEST_SUITE(beast_suite)
 {
   TDOG_TEST_CASE(number_test)
   {
     int num_beast = 665;
     TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(666, ++num_beast); // Passes
   }

   TDOG_TEST_CASE(string_test)
   {
     std::string neighbor_of_beast = "668";
     TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL("668", neighbor_of_beast); // Passes
   }
 }

When accessing test cases with the testdog::runnner class, test cases belonging to suites should always be referred to using the suite name as a prefix.

For example:

 // Disable running of suite
 testdog::runner::global().set_test_enabled("beast_suite::number_test", false);
Parameters:
[in] suite_name 
See also:
TDOG_TEST_CASE()
#define TDOG_SET_AUTHOR ( author_str   ) 

Allows an author name to be associated with the test case.

This macro is intended to be applicable in multi-programmer environments, and provides a means of associating an author name with a test. The author name will be displayed in test reports where applicable.

It should be used within the test implementation as follows:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(some_test)
 {
   TDOG_SET_AUTHOR("Employee 24601");
   ...
 }

The underlying input type is std::string.

Parameters:
[in] author_str Author name (std::string or char*)
#define TDOG_SET_TIME_LIMIT ( sec   ) 

Sets a time limit (in seconds) for the test execution.

If the time taken to execute the test exceeds this value, the test will fail.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(is_prime_func)
 {
   TDOG_SET_TIME_LIMIT(5); // 5 second timeout
   TDOG_ASSERT( is_prime(HUGE_PRIME_NUM) );
 }

A value of 0 (the default) disables the time limit.

Note that the test execution will not be interrupted should if the time exceeds the specified limit. However, the test will enter the failed state when it has finished executing, even if all its test conditions pass.

Where a test case defines its own local time limit, the global time limit (if set) will not apply to that test.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] sec Time limit in seconds
See also:
TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT()
 
#define TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT (  ) 

Designates the test as being exempt from the global time limit setting.

In addition to setting local time limits for test cases using the TDOG_SET_TIME_LIMIT() macro, it is possible to specify a global time limit in the test runner (this will be applied to all tests). For certain tests, however, it may be desirable to exempt them from the global time limit.

This can be achieved with the TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT() as follows:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(is_prime_func)
 {
   TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT();
   TDOG_ASSERT( is_prime(HUGE_PRIME_NUM) );
 }

Note also that where a test case defines its own local time limit, the global time limit (if set) will not apply to that test.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

See also:
TDOG_SET_TIME_LIMIT(), testdog::runner::set_global_time_limit()
 
#define TDOG_TEST_NAME (  ) 

Provides the fully qualified name of the test case to the test's own implementation code.

The TDOG_TEST_NAME() returns a "const char*" value type which points to a name value for the test case.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(some_test)
 {
   printf( "TEST NAME: %s", TDOG_TEST_NAME() );
   ...
 }

The result of TDOG_TEST_NAME() is valid for the duration of the test execution.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Returns:
The test name as a "const char*" type
See also:
TDOG_HAS_TEST_FAILED()
#define TDOG_TEST_REFINST ( test_name   ) 

Allows direct reference to the underlying implementation instance of a test case.

You would not normally need to refer to a test's underlying class instance directly, as tests self-register with the global testdog::runner class. However, if you wish to register test cases explicitly* with the runner yourself by calling its register_test() method, then you will need a mechanism by which to refer to the underlying test instance, and the TDOG_TEST_REFINST() macro provides this.

Below is an example of how to register a test case explicitly with the runner using this macro:

 #include <testdog/unit_test.hpp>

 // Define test
 TDOG_TEST_CASE(some_test)
 {
   ...
 }

 int main(int argc, char **argv)
 {
   // Explicitly register the test
   testdog::runner::global().register_test(TDOG_TEST_REFINST(some_test));
   ...
 }

If the test case belongs within a test suite, you should use the the suite name as a namespaced prefix. For example:

 testdog::runner::global().register_test(TDOG_TEST_REFINST(suite_name::some_test));

You must pre-define the TDOG_DISABLE_AUTO_REG macro to disable to the automatic registration of test cases. See the runner::register_test() method for more information.

Parameters:
[in] test_name Test name
See also:
runner::register_test()
#define TDOG_ASSERT ( a   ) 

Asserts that the test condition "a" is true (the test fails if it is not).

The test's failure condition count is incremented if "a" is false, thus ensuring that the test fails.

Example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(is_prime_func)
 {
   TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT();
   TDOG_TEST_MSG("Go for coffee - this is going to take a long time.");

   TDOG_ASSERT( is_prime(HUGE_PRIME_NUM) );
 }

Where the condition is false, it will be recorded in the test report as a test "fail condition". Pass conditions will also be recored in the reports where the condition is true, but only for "verbose test reports".

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a The test condition
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_MSG ( a,
msg   ) 

Asserts that "a" is true (the test fails if it is not) and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:
[in] a The test condition
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT(), TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL ( a,
b   ) 

Asserts that "a" equals "b" (the test fails if they are not).

Both "a" and "b" must support the equality operator. The test's failure condition count is incremented if they are not equal.

This macro is synonymous with calling:

 TDOG_ASSERT( (a == b) );

Where the terms are not equal, it will recorded in the test report as a test "fail condition". Pass conditions will also be recored in the reports where the terms are equal, but only for "verbose test reports".

When comparing the C-style strings (i.e. char arrays), you may wish to consider using TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL() instead, unless you specifically wish to test for pointer value equality, rather than content.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a Parameter "a"
[in] b Parameter "b"
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG ( a,
b,
msg   ) 

Asserts that "a" equals "b" (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:
[in] a Parameter "a"
[in] b Parameter "b"
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL_MSG()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL ( a,
b   ) 

Asserts that strings "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not).

The parameters "a" and "b" are overloaded for the std::string and std::wstring types. Because these types support C-style strings in their constructors, literal strings can be used as input values.

Example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(case_conversion_test)
 {
   std::string low_str = my_lower_case_func("Hello World");
   TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL("hello world" low_str);

   std::wstring low_wstr = my_wide_lower_case_func(L"Hello World");
   TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL(L"hello world" low_wstr);
 }

Consider using the TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL() macro instead where case insensitive comparisons are required.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a String "a" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] b String "b" passed as std::string or std::wstring
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL_MSG()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL_MSG ( a,
b,
msg   ) 

Asserts that strings "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:
[in] a String "a" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] b String "b" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL ( a,
b   ) 

Compares strings "a" and "b" case insensitively and asserts that they are equal (the test fails if they are not).

The parameters "a" and "b" are overloaded for the std::string and std::wstring types. Because these types support C-style strings in their constructors, literal strings can be used as input values.

IMPORTANT: Only ASCII characters are compared case insensitively.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a String "a" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] b String "b" passed as std::string or std::wstring
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL_MSG()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL_MSG ( a,
b,
msg   ) 

Compares strings "a" and "b" case insensitively and asserts that they are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output. Note that only ASCII characters are compared case insensitively.

Parameters:
[in] a String "a" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] b String "b" passed as std::string or std::wstring
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_STRIC_EQUAL_MSG(), TDOG_ASSERT_STR_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_INT_EQUAL ( a,
b   ) 

Asserts that integer values "a" and "b" are equal.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(test_result)
 {
   TDOG_ASSERT_INT_EQUAL(3, my_sqrt_func(9));
 }

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:

See also:

b,
msg   ) 

Asserts that integer values "a" and "b" are equal and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_INT_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:

TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL ( a,
b,
delta   ) 

Asserts that floating point (double) values "a" and "b" are equal to within the range +/- delta.

This macro asserts that: (a - delta) <= b <= (a + delta).

It may be used to compare floating point values in cases where equality is subject to precision considerations.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(test_sqrt)
 {
   TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL(1.77245, my_sqrt_func(M_PI), 0.00001);
 }

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a Double value "a"
[in] b Double value "b"
[in] delta Range double value
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL_MSG()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL_MSG ( a,
b,
delta,
msg   ) 

Asserts that floating point (double) values "a" and "b" are equal to within the range +/- delta and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:
[in] a Double value "a"
[in] b Double value "b"
[in] delta Range double value
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_DOUBLE_EQUAL()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL ( a,
b,
cnt   ) 

Asserts that the content of arrays "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not).

This macro will compare up to "cnt" array items individually, and the array item type must support the equality operator to facilitate the comparision.

For example:

 int my_sqr(int x) { return x * x; }

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(test_array)
 {
   int a[] = {1, 4, 9};
   int b[] = {my_sqr(1), my_sqr(2), my_sqr(3)};
   TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL(a, b, 3);
 }

Both arrays must contain at least cnt items.

Any data type which which can be indexed using the [] operator, such as std::vector, can be compared using this macro.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] a Array item "a"
[in] b Array item "b"
[in] cnt Number of items to be compared
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL_MSG()
#define TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL_MSG ( a,
b,
cnt,
msg   ) 

Asserts that the content of arrays "a" and "b" are equal (the test fails if they are not) and records the custom message in the test report.

This macro is equivalent to TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL() except that a custom message can be supplied for use in the test report output.

Parameters:
[in] a Array item "a"
[in] b Array item "b"
[in] cnt Number of items to be compared
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(), TDOG_ASSERT_ARRAY_EQUAL()

#define TDOG_TEST_MSG ( msg   ) 

Writes a information message string to the test report.

Information messages appear only in verbose style reports, such as RS_TEXT_VERBOSE. They are ignored for reports which are not considered to be verbose.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(is_prime_func)
 {
   TDOG_SET_GLOBAL_LIMIT_EXEMPT();
   TDOG_TEST_MSG("Go for coffee - this is going to take a long time.");

   TDOG_ASSERT( is_prime(HUGE_PRIME_NUM) );
 }

To write out a formatted value to the report, use TDOG_TEST_VAL() instead.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_TEST_VAL(), TDOG_TEST_PASS(), TDOG_TEST_ERROR(), TDOG_ASSERT_MSG()
#define TDOG_TEST_VAL ( msg,
val   ) 

Writes a formatted value information string to the test report.

This is macro is similar to TDOG_TEST_MSG(), except that it is possible to supply an additional value which will appear in a formatted message. The format is similar to that used in the C printf() function, although syntax and restrictions differ.

The "val" parameter may be of one of the types below.

Integer:

  • long
  • unsigned long
  • int
  • unsigned int
  • short
  • unsigned short
  • bool

Floating Point:

  • float
  • double
  • long double

String:

  • const char*
  • const wchar_t*
  • std::string
  • std::wstring

To identify the location and format of the value in the output, the string "str" should contain one (or more) of the tag specifiers below.

Integer:

  • %(i) - Signed decimal
  • %(u) - Unsigned decimal
  • %(c) - Character
  • %(o) - Signed octal
  • %(x) - Unsigned hex (lower case)
  • %(02x) - 2 digit hex (lower case)
  • %(04x) - 4 digit hex (lower case)
  • %(08x) - 8 digit hex (lower case)
  • %(16x) - 16 digit hex (lower case)
  • %(X) - Unsigned hex (upper case)
  • %(02X) - 2 digit hex (upper case)
  • %(04X) - 4 digit hex (upper case)
  • %(08X) - 8 digit hex (upper case)
  • %(16X) - 16 digit hex (upper case)
  • %(b) - Boolean ("true", or "false")

Floating Point:

  • %(f) - Floating point

String:

  • %(s) - String value
  • %(k) - Escaped string value

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_VAL("final result is 0x%(08X))", rslt);

The supported tag specifiers are not unlike those used in the C printf() function, however, the TDOG_TEST_VAL() macro does not support a variable number of arguments, and the available tag specifiers are restricted to the exact forms above.

Additionally, the "%(b)" and "%(k)" tags have no equivalent in the C printf() function. The "%(b)" is used to represent a boolean value, and is substituted with either "true" or "false". Whereas, the %(k) tag is a string tag, but unlike %(s), ASCII characters less than 0x20 (space) in value will be substitued with "escaped" characters.

These include: "\t", "\n", "\v", "\f" and "\r".

For example, the tab character (0x09) will be replaced with "\t". For other characters, hex digits will be used instead, such as "\x08" for backspace.

Furthermore, the input string "s" may contain multiple tag specifiers, and in this case, all will be substituted with the same value.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_VAL("final result: %(i), HEX: 0x%(08X), OCT:0%(o)", 34283);

Gives the following message output: "final result: 34283, HEX: 0x000085EB, OCT:0102753"

As with TDOG_TEST_MSG(), value formatted messages appear only in verbose style reports, such as RS_TEXT_VERBOSE. They are ignored for reports which are not considered to be verbose.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
[in] val Value
See also:
TDOG_TEST_MSG(), TDOG_TEST_PASS(), TDOG_TEST_ERROR(), TDOG_ASSERT_MSG()
#define TDOG_TEST_FAIL ( msg   ) 

Increments the test case's failure condition count, thus ensuring that the test fails, and writes the supplied message to the test report.

This macro is synonymous with calling:

   TDOG_ASSERT_MSG(false, "A fail message");

Test execution continues after this call, as a test case may implement multiple condition checks.

Note that test case failure messages appear in all test reports, irrespective of whether the report is verbose or not.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_TEST_MSG(), TDOG_TEST_PASS(), TDOG_TEST_ERROR(), TDOG_ASSERT_MSG()
#define TDOG_TEST_PASS ( msg   ) 

Writes a "pass condition" informational message to the test report.

This macro is synonymous with calling:

   TDOG_ASSERT_MSG(true, "A pass message");

It simply outputs an informational message which has a "pass condition" label associated with it--it will not force the test to pass if it has already failed.

As with informational messages written by calling TDOG_TEST_MSG(), "pass messages" appear only in verbose style test reports. They are ignored for reports which are not considered to be verbose.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_TEST_FAIL(), TDOG_TEST_MSG(), TDOG_TEST_ERROR(), TDOG_ASSERT_MSG()
#define TDOG_TEST_ERROR ( msg   ) 

Puts the test case into an error state and writes the supplied message to the test report.

A test case will automically be placed in the "error state" if the test implementation, or its fixture setup/teardown code, throws an unhandled exception. The TDOG_TEST_ERROR() macro, however, can be used to explicitly put the test into an error state from within the test code.

This call is similar to TDOG_TEST_FAIL() in so much as it will effectively prevents the test case from passing. However, a "test error" is considered distinct from a "test failure" because it explicitly refers to a problem in the test implementation code, rather than the code subject to the test.

While test execution will continue normally after a call to TDOG_TEST_ERROR(), typically you would want to terminate the test at this point.

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(customer_add_record)
 {
   // Create initial DB records needed to perform test
   bool setup_ok = setup_customer_add_record_test();

   if (!setup_ok)
   {
     TDOG_TEST_ERROR("Test setup failed - could not perform test");
     return; // <- Exit
   }

   // Actual test
    TDOG_TEST_MSG("Test initialization ok - begin real part of test");
   ...
 }

Note that test error messages are always written to the test report, irrespective of whether the report is verbose or not.

Note. This macro can only be used within the scope of a test case.

Parameters:
[in] msg Message passed as a std::string or C-style string
See also:
TDOG_TEST_FAIL(), TDOG_TEST_MSG(), TDOG_TEST_PASS(), TDOG_ASSERT_MSG()
 
#define TDOG_HAS_TEST_FAILED (  ) 

Provides indication that the test has failed (or raised a test error).

This macro can be used within a test implementation to determine whether any preceeding assert conditions have failed. The result will be true if the test has failed, or is in a test error state.

For example:

 TDOG_TEST_CASE(some_test)
 {
   TDOG_ASSERT_EQUAL(1, 3); // <- Fail

   if (TDOG_HAS_TEST_FAILED())
   {
     TDOG_TEST_MSG("Test already failed - stop here");
     return;
   }

   // Continue testing
   ...
 }
Returns:
Boolean result indicating whether the test has failed
